{{About|the conservative commentator|the researcher and writer|Margaret Gallagher}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox politician |name = Maggie Gallagher |image = MaggieGallagher.JPG |imagesize = |caption = Gallagher in 2010 |pseudonym = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|9|14|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Lake Oswego, Oregon|Lake Oswego]], [[Oregon]], [[United States|U.S.]] |occupation = Commentator |nationality = American |period = |subject = |movement = }}
'''Margaret Gallagher''' (born September 14, 1960) is an American writer and [[Social conservatism in the United States|socially conservative]] [[Pundit (expert)|commentator]]. She wrote a syndicated [[column]] for [[Universal Press Syndicate]] from 1995 to 2013<ref name=MGRetiredColumn>{{cite news|title=Maggie Gallagher and Universal Uclick Announce The Retirement of Gallagher’s Column Read more: The Gilmer Mirror – Maggie Gallagher and Universal Uclick Announce The Retirement of Gallagher’s Column|url=http://www.gilmermirror.com/view/full_story/21294791/article-Maggie-Gallagher-and-Universal-Uclick-Announce-The-Retirement-of-Gallagher%E2%80%99s-Column?instance=secondary_stories_left_column|accessdate=January 4, 2013|newspaper=The Gilmer Mirror Online|date=January 2, 2013}}</ref> and has written books. She serves as president of the Institute for Marriage and Public Policy, a nonprofit organization which lobbies on issues of marriage law. She is an executive committee member, former president and former chairman of the board of the [[National Organization for Marriage]], which opposes same-sex marriage and other legal recognition of same-sex partnerships.<ref name="National Organization for Marriage">{{cite web| url = http://www.nationformarriage.org/site/c.omL2KeN0LzH/b.3479573/k.E2D0/About_NOM.htm| title = About the National Organization for Marriage| publisher = National Organization for Marriage| accessdate = February 16, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationformarriage.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=omL2KeN0LzH&b=5075187&ct=11231037&notoc=1 |title=NOM Announces New Chairman of the Board – National Organization for Marriage |publisher=Nationformarriage.org |date=September 22, 2011 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
== Biography == Maggie Gallagher was born on September 14, 1960 to William Walter Gallagher Sr. and the former Darrilyn Doris Stenz. She is originally from [[Lake Oswego, Oregon]], where she attended [[Lakeridge High School]]. She has three siblings: Kathleen, William Jr., and Colleen.<ref name="ancestry1">{{cite web | url = http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=86401&id=I00629 | title = Amos, Capron, Carnes family | accessdate = October 5, 2009 }}</ref> Her parents were initially active in their local Catholic parish, but her mother left the Church when she was 8, but remained interested in spirituality, while Maggie became what she later described as a "[[pro-life]] atheist" and a reader of [[Ayn Rand]] and [[Robert A. Heinlein]].
In 1982, she earned a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in Religious Studies from [[Yale University]], where she belonged to the [[Party of the Right (Yale)|Party of the Right]] in the [[Yale Political Union]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portsmouthinstitute.org/image_lib/pi_program.pdf|title=Schedule of Events|date=June 2009|publisher=Portsmouth Institute|accessdate=June 27, 2009}}</ref> While at Yale she tried [[marijuana]] once but did not like it.<ref name="salon.com">[http://www.salon.com/2012/02/08/the_making_of_gay_marriages_top_foe/ The making of gay marriage’s top foe]. Salon.com (February 8, 2012). Retrieved on 2016-05-24.</ref>
On October 6, 2010, she returned to the Union to debate against same-sex marriage with opponent [[Evan Wolfson]], executive director of Freedom to Marry and fellow alumnus of the Yale Political Union. Shortly before she was due to graduate, she fell pregnant after a relationship with a fellow party member. She gave birth to a son out of wedlock.<ref name="mgbio"/> She initially planned to put the baby up for adoption but then changed her mind. Neither of the parents thought that they should marry.
She said that the father eventually abandoned her and became uninterested in their child.<ref>{{cite web|last=Oppenheimer|first=Mark|title=The Making of Gay Marriage's Top Foe|url=http://www.salon.com/2012/02/08/the_making_of_gay_marriages_top_foe/|publisher=Salon.com|accessdate=May 21, 2014}}</ref>
In her twenties, she reverted to Catholicism because her experience as a single mother made her consider the necessity of fathers and the linkage of sex to procreation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tennis |first=Cary |url=http://www.salon.com/2012/02/08/the_making_of_gay_marriages_top_foe/ |title=The making of gay marriage’s top foe by Mark Oppenheimer at Salon |publisher=Salon.com |date= |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
Gallagher married Raman Srivastav, a [[Hindu]], in 1993<ref name="salon.com"/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://indiana.bilerico.com/2009/09/maggie_gallagher_-_raman_srivastav.php | title = Maggie Gallagher's husband not welcome at NOM event? | author = Donna Pandori | date = September 30, 2009 | accessdate = October 5, 2009 }}</ref> and they have one son together.
Gallagher attended the premiere reading of ''[[8 (play)|8]]'', [[Dustin Lance Black]]'s play about the trial surrounding California's Proposition 8, where a depiction of her was performed by [[Jayne Houdyshell]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2011/09/anti-gay-nom-activist-maggie-gallagher-attends-staged-broadway-benefit-for-team-challenging-proposit.html |title=Anti-Gay NOM Activist Maggie Gallagher Attends Staged Broadway Benefit for Team Challenging Proposition 8| Gay News |publisher=Towleroad |date=September 20, 2011 |accessdate=November 2, 2013}}</ref> She expressed the opinion that most people would find the work "kind of dull".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://berkshireonstage.com/2012/01/17/8-dustin-lance-blacks-marriage-equality-play-to-be-part-of-williamstown-theatre-festival-2012/ |title=The Story Behind "8" – the Courtroom Drama about Marriage Equality |publisher=Berkshire On Stage |date=January 17, 2012 |accessdate=November 2, 2013}}</ref> In a Los Angeles performance, the Gallagher role was performed by [[Jane Lynch]].
==Career== Gallagher has written several books, including ones with co-author [[Linda J. Waite]], a professor of [[sociology]] at the [[University of Chicago]]. Gallagher serves as president of the Institute for Marriage and Public Policy,<ref name="mgbio">{{cite web| url = http://www.marriagedebate.com/mgbio.php| title = About Maggie| publisher = Institute for Marriage and Public Policy| accessdate = February 16, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125153440/http://www.marriagedebate.com/mgbio.php |archivedate=January 25, 2010}}</ref> a conservative [[think tank]] whose slogan is "strengthening marriage for a new generation."<ref name="mgbio"/><ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.marriagedebate.com/about.php| title = About IMAPP| publisher = Institute for Marriage and Public Policy| accessdate = February 16, 2009}}</ref> She was also President of the [[National Organization for Marriage]] from its founding until April 16, 2010, when [[Brian S. Brown]] took over that role. She maintains a position on NOM's executive committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ontopmag.com/article.aspx?id=5618&MediaType=1&Category=26 |title=Maggie Gallagher Ends Reign Over Anti-Gay Marriage Group |publisher=Ontopmag.com |date=April 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
In late 2011 she founded the Culture War Victory Fund,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lezgetreal.com/2011/12/maggie-gallagher-founds-new-group-ignores-reality/ |title=Maggie Gallagher Founds New Group, Ignores Reality |publisher=Lez Get Real |date=December 6, 2011 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref> and serves as the fund's director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://campaign2012.washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/beltway-confidential/abortion-bill-would-allow-prosecution-providers/238516 |title=Abortion bill would allow prosecution of providers | Campaign 2012 | Washington Examiner |publisher=Campaign2012.washingtonexaminer.com |date=December 5, 2011 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
On January 2, 2013, she announced the retirement of her syndicated column, then distributed by [[Universal Uclick]].<ref name=MGRetiredColumn />
==Social views== Gallagher is a [[Roman Catholic]] and a [[social conservative]].<ref name="Conservative Chronicle">{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativechronicle.com/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=94&twindow=Default&mad=No&sdetail=&wpage=&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=2048&hn=conservativechronicle&he=.com |title=Conservative Chronicle |publisher=Conservative Chronicle |date=July 15, 2009 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref> She is a signatory of the [[Manhattan Declaration: A Call of Christian Conscience|Manhattan Declaration]], a November 2009 ecumenical statement calling on Orthodox, Catholic, and Evangelical Christians not to comply with rules and laws permitting abortion, same-sex marriage and other matters against their religious consciences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manhattandeclaration.org/the-declaration/read.aspx |title=Read the Declaration: A Call of Christian Conscience |publisher=Manhattandeclaration.org |date= |accessdate=February 27, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706023913/http://www.manhattandeclaration.org/the-declaration/read.aspx |archivedate=July 6, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
===Views on abortion=== Gallagher opposes [[abortion]] and believes that ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'' should be overturned. She believes that most people who support legal abortion do so reluctantly because they think it is a necessary evil.<ref>{{cite web|author=Maggie Gallagher |url=http://townhall.com/columnists/MaggieGallagher/2003/01/27/failed_promises_of_abortion |title=Failed promises of abortion |publisher=Townhall.com |date=January 27, 2003 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
===Views on assisted suicide=== Gallagher is opposed to the legalization of [[assisted suicide]] such as the [[Oregon Death with Dignity Act|Death with Dignity Act]] or [[voluntary euthanasia]]. Gallagher believes that state-approved suicide diminishes the value of life, especially for the elderly, sick, or vulnerable.<ref>{{cite web| first= Maggie | last= Gallagher |url=http://townhall.com/columnists/MaggieGallagher/2004/06/02/assisted_suicide_gives_medical_credence_to_self-destruction |title=Assisted suicide gives medical credence to self-destruction |publisher= Townhall.com |date= June 2, 2004 |accessdate= February 27, 2012}}</ref>
===Views on marriage=== Gallagher is a strong opponent of the legal recognition of same-sex unions and has written books toward that end. Gallagher holds that one of the purposes of marriage is always procreation and rearing children exclusively by heterosexual parents,<ref name="whymarriage">{{cite news|url=http://article.nationalreview.com/269352/the-stakes/maggie-gallagher |title=Why we need marriage |author=Gallagher, Maggie |date=July 14, 2003 |accessdate=April 4, 2010 |publisher=[[National Review]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806085511/http://article.nationalreview.com/269352/the-stakes/maggie-gallagher |archivedate=August 6, 2010 |df= }}</ref> and argues that same-sex unions diminish the value of heterosexual marriages. Gallagher has compared winning the fight to ban same-sex marriage with the fall of communism and believes that if same-sex marriage is made legal, it will mean "losing American civilization."<ref name=whymarriage />
Gallagher advocates litigation against spouses who commit adultery and opposes laws which facilitate [[no-fault divorce]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://townhall.com/columnists/MaggieGallagher/2010/03/17/the_right_to_adultery?page=full |title=The Right to Adultery? |publisher=Townhall.com |date=March 17, 2010 |accessdate=November 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanvalues.org/html/r-unhappy_ii.html |title=Does Divorce Make People Happy? Findings from a Study of Unhappy Marriages |publisher=Americanvalues.org |date=June 27, 1997 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
Gallagher has written that "[w]e need a social institution, endowed with public authority, that teaches young men and women [...] that they need to come together in love to raise the children their bodies make together. If this is a core purpose of marriage, then same-sex unions are not marriages. If gay unions are marriages, then this is no longer what marriage is about."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.economist.com/debate/days/view/633 | title=Economist Debates: Single-sex marriage | work=The Economist}}</ref>
Further, Gallagher has written that same-sex marriage is "rooted in a false equation: Loving a man is not the same as loving a woman; a sexual union that can give rise to children is fundamentally different in kind than a union not so freighted, for good and for ill, with the fact of procreativity."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=49572 | title = Why is gay marriage an issue in this campaign? | author = Maggie Gallagher | work = Human Events | publisher = Eagle Publishing, Inc. | date = February 17, 2012 | accessdate = February 23, 2012 }}</ref>
===Views on same-sex relationships=== In October 2006, Gallagher suggested to gay rights groups that they stop promoting same-sex marriage and start vigorously advocating for civil unions.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://townhall.com/columnists/maggiegallagher/2006/10/24/state_marriage_amendment_and_gay_rights_new_dilemmas/page/full | title = State marriage amendment and gay rights: New dilemmas | author = Maggie Gallagher | work = Townhall | date = October 24, 2006 | accessdate = December 22, 2013 }}</ref> In 2010, she expressed her support for certain kinds of civil unions for same-sex couples but not available for opposite-sex couples.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://thenewcivilrightsmovement.com/why-maggie-gallaghers-argument-against-same-sex-marriage-is-wrong/discrimination/2011/03/07/17853 | title = UPDATED: Why Maggie Gallagher’s Argument Against Same-Sex Marriage Is Wrong | author = David Badash | work = The New Civil Rights movement | date = March 7, 2011 | accessdate = December 22, 2013 }}</ref> However, she, in 2012, supported [[North Carolina Amendment 1|North Carolina's Amendment 1]], a state constitutional amendment that bans both recognition of same-sex marriages and civil unions.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://m.nationalreview.com/corner/299350/apologies-rod-sort-maggie-gallagher | title = Apologies to Rod (Sort Of) | author = Maggie Gallagher | work = National Review | date = May 8, 2012 | accessdate = December 22, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://m.nationalreview.com/corner/299350/apologies-rod-sort-maggie-gallagher | title = The Margin of Victory in North Carolina | author = Maggie Gallagher | work = National Review | date = May 9, 2012 | accessdate = December 22, 2013 }}</ref>
Gallagher believes that many people in the [[LGBT]] community, specifically gay men, choose to oppose what they label as the "[[heteronormative]]" constraints of a [[monogamy|monogamous relationship]], with reference to [[Eric Erbelding]]'s assertion that the married gay couples he knows are "for the most part monogamous, but for maybe a casual three-way".<ref name=steve>{{cite news|url=http://article.nationalreview.com/print/?q=ZGNmODNiMjI0MTQ1MTQwNGM4N2YyNmVhY2UyZTE0OWY= |title=Redefinition Revolution |publisher=''[[National Review]]'' |date=June 17, 2008 |accessdate=August 13, 2010 |first=Maggie |last=Gallagher |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629075454/http://article.nationalreview.com/print/?q=ZGNmODNiMjI0MTQ1MTQwNGM4N2YyNmVhY2UyZTE0OWY%3D |archivedate=June 29, 2008 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Gallagher had previously expressed opposition to [[domestic partnerships]] and [[civil unions]], and she believes that domestic partner benefits "erode the status" of heterosexual marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.protectmaineequality.org/release.cfm?id=162|title=Yes Campaign Ad Promoting Domestic Partnerships a Sham|accessdate=August 13, 2010|publisher=protectmaineequality.org}}</ref> She has stated that same-sex marriage is worse than polygamy, which/"for all its ugly defects, is an attempt to secure stable mother-father families for children."<ref name=whymarriage />
Gallagher has stated that "[s]exual orientation is almost certainly unchosen", but that the decision to act on that desire and to incorporate it into one’s identity is a choice that bears moral reflection. She believes that "sexual desire is not its own justification" for acceptance or legal recognition of same-sex relationships.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://article.nationalreview.com/395223/redefining-religious-liberty/maggie-gallagher |title=Redefining Religious Liberty |publisher=Article.nationalreview.com |date=May 27, 2009 |accessdate=February 27, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809220727/http://article.nationalreview.com/395223/redefining-religious-liberty/maggie-gallagher |archivedate=August 9, 2010 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> She has also written that "once the principle [of same-sex marriage] is in the law, the next step will be to use the law to stigmatize, marginalize, and repress those who disagree with the government’s new views on marriage and sexual orientation." As an example, she has cited efforts by LGBT advocates to revoke the tax-exempt status of churches that oppose same-sex marriage.<ref name=steve/>
Gallagher has stated that she will not attend a same-sex wedding if she is ever invited to one.<ref>Maggie Gallagher (April 17, 2015) [http://www.nationalreview.com/article/417062/why-i-unlike-senator-rubio-would-not-attend-gay-wedding-maggie-gallagher Why I, Unlike Senator Rubio, Would Not Attend a Gay Wedding]. nationalreview.com</ref>
===Views on sex education=== Gallagher believes that teaching [[abstinence-only sex education|abstinence]] (encouraging celibacy until legally married) should be the sole curriculum. She does not believe in instructing students in birth control or how to prevent STDs through use of condoms or safe-sex techniques and has advocated discontinuing all safer-sex education in public schools.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gallagher |first=Maggie |url=http://townhall.com/columnists/MaggieGallagher/2010/02/03/about_that_new_abstinence_study?page=full&comments=true |title=About That New Abstinence Study (archived) |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=November 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209125714/http://townhall.com/columnists/MaggieGallagher/2010/02/03/about_that_new_abstinence_study?page=full&comments=true |archivedate=February 9, 2010 }}</ref>
===Views on single parenting=== When [[Dan Quayle]] criticized the fictional television character [[Murphy Brown]] for being an unwed mother, Gallagher wrote an op-ed for ''[[The New York Times]]'', "An Unwed Mother for Quayle", in his defense.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholiceducation.org/articles/marriage/mf0006.html |title=An Unwed Mother For Quayle |publisher=Catholiceducation.org |date= |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref>
===Presidential election=== Gallagher's endorsement of candidate [[Rick Santorum]] in the 2012 Republican presidential primaries was promoted by the Santorum campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0112/71435.html |title=Rick Santorum: Ron Paul doesn't stand for life – James Hohmann |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Bill Fox |url=http://data.greenvilleonline.com/blogs/politics/2012/01/13/former-chairman-of-the-national-organization-for-marriage-endorses/ |title=Former Chairman Of The National Organization For Marriage Endorses Santorum – Politics |publisher=Data.greenvilleonline.com |date=January 13, 2012 |accessdate=February 27, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120717053844/http://data.greenvilleonline.com/blogs/politics/2012/01/13/former-chairman-of-the-national-organization-for-marriage-endorses/ |archivedate=July 17, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Federal contracts scandal== Gallagher received tens of thousands of dollars from the [[Department of Health and Human Services]] during 2002 and 2003 for helping the [[George W. Bush administration]] promote the President's Healthy Marriage Initiative.<ref name=Kurtz /> Gallagher testified before Congress in favor of "healthy marriage" programs but never disclosed the payments.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washblade.com/2005/2-4/news/national/hrcseek.cfm |title=HRC seeks investigation of columnist Gallagher – Writer failed to disclose grants in congressional testimony |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422032717/http://www.washblade.com/2005/2-4/news/national/hrcseek.cfm |archivedate=April 22, 2009 |work=[[Washington Blade]] |date=February 4, 2005 |first=Joe |last=Crea}}</ref> When asked about that situation, she replied, "Did I violate journalistic ethics by not disclosing it? I don't know. You tell me…frankly, it never occurred to me."<ref name=Kurtz>{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A36545-2005Jan25.html | title = Writer Backing Bush Plan Had Gotten Federal Contract | author = Howard Kurtz | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = January 26, 2005 | accessdate = March 25, 2010 }}</ref>
After ''[[The Washington Post]]'' revealed this information on January 26, 2005, Gallagher claimed significant differences between her situation and that of conservative columnist [[Armstrong Williams]]. She went on to add, "I should have disclosed a government contract when I later wrote about the Bush marriage initiative. I would have, if I had remembered it. My apologies to my readers."<ref name="response">{{cite web |first=Maggie |last=Gallagher |year=2005 |title=A Question of Disclosure |url=http://www.uexpress.com/printable/print.html?uc_full_date=20050125&uc_comic=mg |publisher=uexpress}}</ref>
Gallagher received an additional $20,000 from the Bush administration for writing a report, titled ''Can Government Strengthen Marriage?'', for the National Fatherhood Initiative, a private organization.<ref name="Kurtz" />
==Conversion therapy==
On a February 2012 edition of ''[[Up with Chris Hayes]]'' on which Gallagher appeared for a segment on the revival of the "culture wars", Gallagher was asked by ''[[The Nation]]'' editor Richard Kim about her support of [[conversion therapy|gay reparative therapy]]. Gallagher denied having ever supported ex-gay therapy and claimed that Kim was "making stuff up".<ref name=Whitman>{{cite news | url = http://www.thenation.com/blog/166218/w-chris-hayes-richard-kim-challenges-noms-maggie-gallagher-her-support-ex-gay-therapy | title = Fixing Sexual Orientation | author = Elizabeth Whitman | work = The Nation | date = February 13, 2012 | accessdate = February 27, 2012 }}</ref> Kim subsequently quoted from a 2001 column written by Gallagher praising [[Robert Spitzer (psychiatrist)|Robert Spitzer]] for his research on the possibilities of ex-gay therapy and calling on then-President [[George W. Bush]] to support federal funding for research into ex-gay therapy.<ref name=Townhall>{{cite news | url = http://townhall.com/columnists/maggiegallagher/2001/05/10/fixing_sexual_orientation/page/full/ | title = Fixing Sexual Orientation | author = Maggie Gallagher | work = Townhall | date = May 10, 2001 | accessdate = February 27, 2012 }}</ref> In 2013, after blogging her support for [[Charles LiMandri|Chuck Limandri's]] representation of [[JONAH]] (a Jewish organization that offered support to persons with unwanted same-sex attraction),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/corner/chuck-limandri-vs-splc-maggie-gallagher//|work=NationalReview.com|title=Chuck Limandri vs. the SPLC|last=Gallagher|first=Maggie|date=2013-07-15|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref> Gallagher made the following comments<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/corner/record-its-not-conversion-therapy-im-backing-maggie-gallagher/|work=NationalReview.com|title=For the Record: It’s Not Conversion Therapy I’m Backing|last=Gallagher|first=Maggie|date=2013-07-18|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref> regarding conversion therapy: {{Quote |text=I don’t back something called "conversion therapy." I don’t even really know what conversion therapy is, and I’m not qualified to express an opinion on a particular kind of therapy.
I back the right of gay people to seek the kind of counseling help they want, not the kind the [Southern Poverty Law Center] lawyers want them to have, including help to live their sexual lives with integrity, according to their own values, not the SPLC’s values. That’s all. }}

Waite (2001). {{ISBN|0-7679-0632-2}}. * ''The Case for Staying Married'' with Linda J. Waite (2005). {{ISBN|0-19-516929-8}}. * ''Debating Same-Sex Marriage'' with [[John Corvino]] (2012). '''Orthodoxy in Azerbaijan''' is the second largest religious group in the [[Azerbaijan|Republic of Azerbaijan]] (after [[Islam]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/171683.pdf|title=Religion in Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=8P3pOV4CWJsC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=orthodoxy+in+azerbaijan#v=onepage&q=orthodoxy%20in%20azerbaijan&f=false|title=Russia and the New States of Eurasia: The Politics of Upheaval|last=Dawisha|first=Karen|last2=Parrott|first2=Bruce|date=1994-01-28|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521458955|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nato-pfp.mfa.gov.az/files/file/broch_AZE-OTAN_LR.pdf|title=All about Azerbaijan: culture, religion and etc|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> According to statistics, the Orthodox [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] tradition in Azerbaijan is 2.3% (209.7 thousand people). The territory of Azerbaijan is in the jurisdiction<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spc.rs/eng/russian_church_has_180_million_faithful_36000_churches_1000_monasteries_56_seminariespat_kirill|title=Russian Church has 180 million faithful; 36,000 churches; 1,000 monasteries; 56 seminaries—pat. Kirill {{!}} Serbian Orthodox Church [Official web site]|website=www.spc.rs|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref> of the Baku-Azerbaijan Diocese of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://biblio.ugent.be/publication/8539216/file/8539225.pdf|title=Russian Orthodox Church and its influence|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eurasianet.org/s/the-russian-orthodox-church-and-the-impact-of-bolshevism|title=The Russian Orthodox Church and the Impact of Bolshevism|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en}}</ref>
== History of Orthodoxy in Azerbaijan == {| class="wikitable" |Year | colspan="2" |Total numbers |Slavic-Orthodox population share<ref name=":0" /> |- |1897 | colspan="2" |95,736 |5.6 |- |1926 | colspan="2" |241,653 |0.6 |- |1939 | colspan="2" |553,433 |17.3 |- |1959 | colspan="2" |531,344 |14.3 |- |1970 | colspan="2" |544,148 |10.6 |- |1979 | colspan="2" |506,439 |8.4 |- |1989 | colspan="2" |432,482 |6.2 |- | colspan="2" |1999 |170,700 |2.1 |- | colspan="2" |2009 |143,800 |1.6 |} Serious changes in the [[Albanian Orthodox Church|Albanian church]] occurred under the Arab rule, when the Catholicos Nerses I Bakur (688-704) attempted to convert to Chalcedonism, thus recognizing the spiritual authority of [[Constantinople]]. He was deposed by the Grand Duke of Albania Shero and other feudal lords who remained faithful to the Albanian church, and cursed at the national church cathedral. In the second half of the 10th century, the population of the left-bank Albania (Hereti) was included in the sphere of influence of the decision of the Chalcedon Council of the [[Georgian Orthodox Church|Georgian Church]], adopted in the 7th century and got a great impact of Georgia.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sgW_HEcULMYC&pg=PA158&lpg=PA158&dq=catholicosate+albania#v=onepage&q=catholicosate%20albania&f=false|title=From the Gulf to Central Asia: Players in the New Great Game|last=Ehteshami|first=Anoushiravan|date=1994|publisher=University of Exeter Press|isbn=9780859894517|language=en}}</ref>
When the territories of [[Transcaucasia]] entered the [[Russian Empire]], the Albanian Catholicos of the church in 1813 by the decree of [[Nicholas I of Russia|Tsar Nicholas I]] passed into the status of the [[Metropolitan bishop|metropolite]] of the Albanian church.
Orthodoxy became wide spread in Azerbaijan at the beginning of the 19th century.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://multiculturalism.preslib.az/en_a4.html|title=Azerbaijani Multiculturalism|last=Huseynzadeh|first=Tunjay|website=multiculturalism.preslib.az|language=en|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lib.aliyev-heritage.org/en/7855792.html|title=Welcome to Heydar Aliyevs Heritage Research Center|website=lib.aliyev-heritage.org|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
== Orthodoxy in Azerbaijan nowadays == In 1815, the first Russian Orthodox church appeared in [[Baku]]. Later such churches were built in [[Ganja, Azerbaijan|Ganja]], [[Goranboy (city)|Goranboy]] (Borisi-Russian village, 1842), [[Shamakhi|Shemakha]] (Alty-Aghadj village, 1834), [[Lankaran]] (Vel village, 1838), and [[Gadabay District|Gedabek]] (Slavyanka village, 1844).
There were 21 sectarian villages in Baku during 1868.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.azerbaijan.az/_GeneralInfo/_TraditionReligion/_traditionReligion_e.html|title=Azerbaijan - Religion In Azerbaijan|website=www.azerbaijan.az|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
In 1905, the Baku Diocese of the Russian Orthodox Church was established. During the Soviet era,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.upenn.edu/journals/jil/articles/volume33/issue2/BlittBoyd33U.Pa.J.Int'lL.363(2011).pdf|title=Religion in USSR|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the authorities repressed the priests of the Baku diocese, but in 1944 two churches were opened.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://myangle.net/en/angle/899-russian-orthodox-church-baku|title=Russian Orthodox Church in Baku|work=MyAngle|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
In 1998, the Baku-Caspian Diocese of the Russian Orthodox Church was established. On March 22, 2011, the decision of the Holy Synod of the Russian Orthodox Church was changed to the Baku-Caspian diocese in Baku-Azerbaijan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mospat.ru/en/2010/12/25/news33364/|title=Holy Synod of the Russian Orthodox Church takes decisions on external church activities {{!}} The Russian Orthodox Church|website=mospat.ru|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
In 2011 there were six Christian Orthodox churches in the country. Five of them belong to the Russian Orthodox church (ROC): three of them are located in Baku one in Ganja and one in [[Khachmaz (city)|Khachmaz]].
Another temple belongs to the jurisdiction of the Georgian Orthodox Church - the church of [[Saint George|St. George]] in the village of Gakh-Inguila in the [[Qakh District|Qakh district]], where the [[Ingiloy people|Ingiloi]] Georgians<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://matiane.wordpress.com/2010/08/16/activity-of-russian-orthodox-church-among-the-muslim-natives-of-the-caucasus-in-imperial-russia/|title=ACTIVITY OF RUSSIAN ORTHODOX CHURCH AMONG THE MUSLIM NATIVES OF THE CAUCASUS IN IMPERIAL RUSSIA|date=2010-08-16|work=მატიანე|access-date=2018-05-31|language=ka-GE}}</ref> live compactly (about 7,500 people).
In 2013, November, President [[Ilham Aliyev]] participated in the opening ceremony of Orthodox Religious and Cultural Center of Baku and Azerbaijan Eparchy. Firstly<sup>,</sup> The President visited the [[Holy Myrrhbearers Cathedral]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theorthodoxchurch.info/blog/news/azerbaijani-president-attends-opening-of-orthodox-religious-and-cultural-center-of-baku-and-azerbaijan-eparchy/|title=Azerbaijani President attends opening of Orthodox Religious and Cultural Center of Baku and Azerbaijan Eparchy|date=2013-11-16|work=News {{!}} Orthodoxy Cognate PAGE|access-date=2018-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
There is also the [[Michael (archangel)|Michael]] Archangel’s Temple in the capital city Baku.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archangel-mikhail-baku.com/en/about-us/|title=About us – Church of St. Archangel Michael of Baku|website=archangel-mikhail-baku.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
== The Albanian-Udin Christian community == In 2001, during his visit to Azerbaijan, Patriarch Alexe II met with representatives of the Udin community who expressed the desire of their people to join the ROC. However, this did not lead to any real results, and the community of Udin remained outside the church's nourishment.
In May 28, 2003, the Albanian-Udin Christian community was established in Azerbaijan. The Chairman of the community was Robert Mobilea. This was due to the restoration of the ancient Kish temple in [[Shaki, Azerbaijan|Shaki]] (according to legend, the foundation was laid by the apostle Eliseus). In 2006, the restoration of the second Udin temple, the church in the village of Nijgabalinsky district, was completed. Restoration works are also continued in the village of Gum of the Gakh region and the basilica in the village of Gyumriuk with the intention of restoration of the Albanian basilica which is related to the 5th century.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/ai113_folder/113_articles/113_udins_konanchev.html|title=Udins Today - Ancestors of the Caucasian Albanians|last=|first=|date=|website=www.azer.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
In 2006, the bishop of Baku and the Caspian Sea, Alexander (Ishchein), reported that Orthodox worship will be performed in Udin churches, and priests for them are trained in Russian religious schools. The Baku diocese of the Russian Orthodox Church took part in some solemn events, and even held baptisms, but there is no general progress on the involving of Udin into the ROC. Meanwhile, the Albanian-Udin Christian community exists in the form of a separate ethno-religious group with its own ideas about the "Udin Church", in which rituals are conducted not by canonical clergymen, but by the members of the community. In particular, the right to baptize was taken over by the Chairman of the AUHO Robert Mobilea and the self-styled "spiritual figure" Rafik Danakari.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.baku.ru/blg-list.php?id=103190|title=Baptism in Nij|last=|first=|date=|website=www.baku.ru|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref>
